user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetHostName:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(name_len);

    /* delegate to low-level API */
    return_code = OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(host_name, name_len);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return an empty string on failure, just in case */
        host_name[0] = 0;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_NetworkGetHostName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    if (gethostname(host_name, name_len) < 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * posix does not say that the name is always
         * null terminated, so its worthwhile to ensure it
         */
        host_name[name_len - 1] = 0;
        return_code             = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
void OS_printf(const char *String, ...)
{
    va_list va;
    char    msg_buffer[OS_BUFFER_SIZE];
    int     actualsz;

    BUGCHECK_VOID(String != NULL)

    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_INIT_MAGIC_NUMBER)
    {
        /*
         * Catch some historical mis-use of the OS_printf() call.
         *
         * Typically OS_printf() should NOT be called before OS_API_Init().
         *
         * This was never guaranteed to work, particularly on a VxWorks
         * deployment where the utility task was enabled.
         *
         * However, some PSPs do this, particularly those that used POSIX
         * where it happened to work (because OS_printf just called printf).
         *
         * As a workaround, use the OS_DEBUG facility to dump the message,
         * along with a clue that this API is being used inappropriately.
         *
         * If debugging is not enabled, then this message will be silently
         * discarded.
         */
        OS_DEBUG("BUG: OS_printf() called when OSAL not initialized: %s", String);
    }
    else if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.PrintfEnabled)
    {
        /* Format and determine the size of string to write */
        va_start(va, String);
        actualsz = vsnprintf(msg_buffer, sizeof(msg_buffer), String, va);
        va_end(va);

        if (actualsz < 0)
        {
            /* unlikely: vsnprintf failed */
            actualsz = 0;
        }
        else if (actualsz >= OS_BUFFER_SIZE)
        {
            /* truncate */
            actualsz = OS_BUFFER_SIZE - 1;
        }

        msg_buffer[actualsz] = 0;

        OS_ConsoleWrite(OS_SharedGlobalVars.PrintfConsoleId, msg_buffer);
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragment in the provided code assigns to a pointer parameter variable itself. MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 forbids modifying the parameter object that holds the pointer (e.g. doing `host_name = ...`), but allows modifying the object pointed to (e.g. `host_name[0] = 0`). The following points justify why other fragments need not be investigated:

- In OS_NetworkGetHostName, the only operations on the parameter `host_name` are: the NULL check macro OS_CHECK_POINTER(host_name), passing it to OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(host_name, name_len), and writing to the pointee (`host_name[0] = 0`) when an error occurs. Writing to the pointee is permitted by the rule; there is no assignment to the parameter variable itself.

- In OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl, the pointer parameter `host_name` is passed to gethostname(host_name, name_len) and an element of the pointee is set (`host_name[name_len - 1] = 0`). Both are modifications of the pointed-to object (allowed). There is no code that reassigns `host_name`.

- The macros OS_CHECK_POINTER and OS_CHECK_SIZE expand to checks (BUGCHECK/ARGCHECK) that only evaluate the expressions; they do not perform assignments to the parameter variable.

- Other shown functions/macros (e.g. OS_printf, vsnprintf usage) either take const pointer parameters or only read/forward the pointer; they do not assign to the parameter variables.

Therefore, there are no fragments in the supplied code that appear to violate Rule 17.8 (no pointer parameter variable is modified).
